answers.text: the U.S. Supreme Court did not invalidate any federal statute as exceeding Congress' power under the Commerce Clause.

context: From 1938 until 1995, <a0_0><b5_0>the <b6_0>U.S. Supreme Court did not invalidate any federal statute as exceeding Congress' power under the Commerce Clause<b6_0/>.<b5_0/><a0_0/> Most actions by the federal government can find some legal support among the express powers, such as the <a1_0><b7_0>Commerce Clause<b7_0/><a1_0/>, whose applicability has been narrowed by the Supreme Court in recent years. In 1995 <a2_0>the <b8_0>Supreme Court rejected the Gun-Free School Zones Act<b8_0/> in the Lopez decision<a2_0/>, and also <a3_0>rejected <b9_0>the civil remedy portion of the Violence Against Women Act<b9_0/><a3_0/> of 1994 in the United States v. Morrison decision. Recently, the Commerce Clause was interpreted to <a4_0>include marijuana laws in the Gonzales v. Raich decision<a4_0/>.
